Miki K. Sato H. Seiki M. Miyazaki K. J. Biochem. ( Tokyo ). 1998; 124: 462-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Okada et al. (11Okada A. Tomasetto C. Lutz Y. Bellocq J.-P. Rio M.-C. Basset P. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 137: 67-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar) also reported that ConA stimulates rat fibroblasts to augment the production of MT1-MMP and the activation of pro-MMP-2. In the present study, we confirmed that ConA augmented the gene expression and production of MT1-MMP and the subsequent pro-MMP-2 activation in rabbit dermal fibroblasts (Fig. 1). It is therefore likely that MT1-MMP production and pro-MMP-2 activation increased by ConA are commonly observed in various cell species and origins. Human MT1-MMP mAb and cDNA recognized rabbit MT1-MMP protein and mRNA, respectively (Fig. 1). It is therefore of interest whether the rabbit MT1-MMP recognized by human MT1-MMP mAb would functionally participate in pro-MMP-2 activation. From this point of view, we demonstrated that in vitro pro-MMP-2 activation induced by plasma membranes from ConA-treated rabbit dermal fibroblasts was effectively inhibited by exogenously adding human MT1-MMP mAb (Fig. 2). A similar inhibitory effect of MT1-MMP mAb was observed in the case of the membrane fraction from the ConA-treated human uterine cervical fibroblasts (40Ito A. Yamada M. Sato T. Sanekata K. Sato H. Seiki M. Nagase H. Mori Y. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 251: 353-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). On the other hand, rabbit MT1-MMP cDNA was recently characterized in rabbit osteoclasts (30Sato T. Ovejero M.C. Hou P. Heegaard A.-M. Kumegawa M. Foged N.T. Delaisse J.-M. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 589-596Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and arterial smooth muscle cells (31Wang H. Keiser J.A. J. Vasc. Res. 1998; 35: 45-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar), and the deduced amino acid sequence shows 96% identity to human MT1-MMP, but only 57, 52, and 38% identity to human MT2-MMP, MT3-MMP, and MT4-MMP, respectively. Taken together, these results strongly suggest that rabbit MT1-MMP is functionally identical to human MT1-MMP in its pro-MMP-2 activation. Since the propeptide of pro-MT1-MMP contains RRKR which is a recognition sequence of the intracellular processing enzyme furin, it is considered that the activation of proMT1-MMP by furin is automatically accomplished in the trans-Golgi network (9Sato H. Takino T. Okada Y. Cao J. Shinagawa A. Yamamoto E. Seiki M. Nature. 1994; 370: 61-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (2379) Google Scholar, 19Sato H. Kinoshita T. Takino T. Nakayama K. Seiki M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 393: 101-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (302) Google Scholar). Our results showed that furin mRNA and its enzymic activity were detected in both rabbit dermal and human uterine cervical fibroblasts (Fig. 3). Furthermore, neither furin mRNA expression nor its intracellular activity was altered by ConA in both fibroblast types (Fig. 3). Santavicca et al. (47Santavicca M. Noel A. Angliker H. Stoll I. Segain J.-P. Anglard P. Chretien M. Seidah N. Basset P. Biochem. J. 1996; 315: 953-958Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar) reported that the gene expression of furin in human diploid HFL1 fibroblasts is not regulated by phorbol ester, which is an inducer of MT1-MMP production in human fibroblasts and human fibrosarcoma HT-1080 cells (48Strongin A.Y. Marmer B.L. Grant G.A. Goldberg G.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14033-14039Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 49Lohi J. Lehti K. Westermarck J. Kähäri V.-M. Keski-Oja J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 239: 239-247Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). Taken together, these results suggest that, unlike MT1-MMP production, the furin gene expression and intracellular activity cannot be substantially regulated by stimuli such as ConA and phorbol ester. Mouse and human furin cDNAs have been cloned, and the homologies of their cDNA and amino acid sequences are 96 and 94%, respectively (21Hatsuzawa K. Hosaka M. Nakagawa T. Nagase M. Shoda A. Murakami K. Nakayama K. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 22075-22078Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 36Van den Ouweland A.M.W. Van Duijnhoven H.L.P. Keizer G.D. Dorssers C.J. Van de Ven W.J.M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 664Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar). We demonstrated that furin cDNA (405 bp) amplified in rabbit dermal fibroblasts was the same as the cDNA sequence of human furin (data not shown). These results strongly suggest that the furin gene might be conserved over cell species. Furthermore, this is the first evidence that rabbit furin cDNA is identical to human furin, at least partially. It has been reported that a specific furin inhibitor, Dec-RVKR-CH2Cl, inhibits the activation of human pro-MMP-11 (47Santavicca M. Noel A. Angliker H. Stoll I. Segain J.-P. Anglard P. Chretien M. Seidah N. Basset P. Biochem. J. 1996; 315: 953-958Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar) and pro-MT1-MMP (50Maquoi E. Noël A. Frankenne F. Angliker H. Murphy G. Foidart J.-M. FEBS Lett. 1998; 424: 262-266Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). We demonstrated that the ConA-induced pro-MMP-2 activation in human uterine cervical fibroblasts was inhibited by Dec-RVKR-CH2Cl but not by the nonspecific furin inhibitor Dec-RAIR-CH2Cl (Fig. 4 B). In addition, F-AS but not F-S inhibited the ConA-induced pro-MMP-2 activation in the human fibroblasts (Fig. 5 B). Our results coincided with previous reports indicating that human MT1-MMP processing is mediated by furin. In contrast, neither the specific furin inhibitor nor F-AS inhibited the MT1-MMP-mediated pro-MMP-2 activation in ConA-treated rabbit dermal fibroblasts (Figs. 4 A and 5 A) regardless of whether a furin recognition sequence RRKR was contained in the propeptide of rabbit MT1-MMP (30Sato T. Ovejero M.C. Hou P. Heegaard A.-M. Kumegawa M. Foged N.T. Delaisse J.-M. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 589-596Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 31Wang H. Keiser J.A. J. Vasc. Res. 1998; 35: 45-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). We further demonstrated that F-AS specifically and completely suppressed the expression of furin mRNA in both rabbit and human fibroblasts (Fig. 6). These results strongly suggest that furin is not required for the intracellular processing of MT1-MMP in rabbit dermal fibroblasts, and therefore the involvement of furin in MT1-MMP activation may be dependent on the animal species. Furin belongs to the family of subtilisin/Kex 2p-like proprotein convertases, and six distinct convertases (PC2, PC1/PC3, PACE4, PC4, PC5/PC6, and LPC/PC7/PC8/SPC7) in this family have been identified in mammalian species. It has also been reported that furin, PACE4, PC/5PC6, and LPC/PC7/PC8/SPC7 are expressed in a broad range of tissues and cell lines (for review, see Ref. 51Nakayama K. Biochem. J. 1997; 327: 625-635Crossref PubMed Scopus (705) Google Scholar). Furthermore, the expression patterns of these convertases are different in some physiological conditions such as embryogenesis and gestation (52Marcinkiewicz M. Day R. Seidah N.G. Chretien M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 4922-4926Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar, 53Marcinkiewicz M. Ramla D. Seidah N.G. Chretien M. Endocrinology. 1994; 135: 1651-1660Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 54Zheng M. Seidah N.G. Pintar J.E. Dev. Biol. 1997; 181: 268-283Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). In the present study, our finding that furin is not required for MT1-MMP activation in rabbit dermal fibroblasts regardless of the detectable enzymic activity suggests that other subtilisin/Kex 2p-like convertases may be involved in rabbit MT1-MMP activation. This hypothesis can be supported by previous studies. Other convertases such as PACE4, PC5/PC6, and LPC/PC7/PC8/SPC7 have been shown to possess enzymic properties similar to those of furin (51Nakayama K. Biochem. J. 1997; 327: 625-635Crossref PubMed Scopus (705) Google Scholar). Santavicca et al. (47Santavicca M. Noel A. Angliker H. Stoll I. Segain J.-P. Anglard P. Chretien M. Seidah N. Basset P. Biochem. J. 1996; 315: 953-958Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar) also reported that the activation of human pro-MMP-11 is mediated specifically by furin, but mouse pro-MMP-11 activation is accomplished by both furin and PACE4. In conclusion, we demonstrated for the first time that in both rabbit and human fibroblasts ConA increased MT1-MMP production and thereby augmented pro-MMP-2 activation, whereas the furin gene and its enzymic activity was constitutively expressed and not influenced by ConA. Furthermore, the increased pro-MMP-2 activation was specifically inhibited by the synthetic furin inhibitor and F-AS in the ConA-treated human fibroblasts but not in rabbit fibroblasts. These results suggest a cell type-specific involvement of furin in the process of MT1-MMP activation.

p21c-Ha-Ras (Ras) can be activated by the guanine nucleotide exchange factor mSOS1 or byS-nitrosylation of cysteine 118 via nitric oxide (NO). To determine whether these two Ras-activating mechanisms modulate distinct biological effects, a NO-nonresponsive Ras mutant (RasC118S) was stably expressed in the PC12 cells, a cell line that generates NO upon nerve growth factor treatment. We report here that RasC118S functions indistinguishably from wild type Ras in activating and maintaining the mSOS1- and Raf-1-dependent mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade necessary for neuronal differentiation. However, continuous (>5 days) exposure to nerve growth factor reveals that, in contrast to parental or wild-type Ras-overexpressing PC12 cells, RasC118S-expressing PC12 cells cannot sustain the basal interaction between Ras and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase. This results in spontaneous apoptosis of these cells despite the presence of nerve growth factor and serum. Thus unique downstream effector interactions and biological outcomes can be differentially modulated by distinct modes of Ras activation. p21c-Ha-Ras (Ras) can be activated by the guanine nucleotide exchange factor mSOS1 or byS-nitrosylation of cysteine 118 via nitric oxide (NO). To determine whether these two Ras-activating mechanisms modulate distinct biological effects, a NO-nonresponsive Ras mutant (RasC118S) was stably expressed in the PC12 cells, a cell line that generates NO upon nerve growth factor treatment. We report here that RasC118S functions indistinguishably from wild type Ras in activating and maintaining the mSOS1- and Raf-1-dependent mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade necessary for neuronal differentiation. However, continuous (>5 days) exposure to nerve growth factor reveals that, in contrast to parental or wild-type Ras-overexpressing PC12 cells, RasC118S-expressing PC12 cells cannot sustain the basal interaction between Ras and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase. This results in spontaneous apoptosis of these cells despite the presence of nerve growth factor and serum. Thus unique downstream effector interactions and biological outcomes can be differentially modulated by distinct modes of Ras activation. nerve growth factor guanine nucleotide exchange factor mitogen-activated protein nitric-oxide synthase sodium nitroprusside phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase The monomeric G protein p21c-Ha-Ras (Ras) is a prototypic member of the Ras superfamily of small GTPases (1Denhardt D.T. Biochem. J. 1996; 318: 729-747Crossref PubMed Scopus (454) Google Scholar, 2Bos J.L. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 6776-6782Crossref PubMed Scopus (288) Google Scholar). Its primary function is to relay extracellular inputs from various growth factors to distinct intracellular signaling pathways, leading to long term biological outcomes unique to each stimulus and cell type. In the nerve growth factor (NGF)1-responsive cell line PC12, the molecular cascade of Ras activation via the guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) mSOS1 and the downstream biological effects have been described in some detail (3Lewin G.R. Barde Y.A. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1996; 19: 289-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (1788) Google Scholar, 4Greene L.A. Kaplan D.R. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 579-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 5Segal R.A. Greenberg M.E. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1996; 19: 463-489Crossref PubMed Scopus (908) Google Scholar). Specifically, NGF maintains the survival of serum-deprived PC12 cells (6Greene L.A. J. Cell Biol. 1978; 78: 747-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar) and induces the progressive differentiation of these cells into a sympathetic neuron-like phenotype (7Greene L.A. Tischler A.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1976; 73: 2424-2428Crossref PubMed Scopus (4873) Google Scholar) via activation of the NGF receptor Trk A (8Hempstead B.L. Rabin S.J. Kaplan L. Reid S. Parada L.F. Kaplan D.R. Neuron. 1992; 9: 883-896Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (286) Google Scholar). Activated Trk A recruits several signal-transducing molecules that include components of the mSOS1-Ras-MAP kinase cascade and phosphatidylinositol (PI) 3-kinase (4Greene L.A. Kaplan D.R. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 579-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 5Segal R.A. Greenberg M.E. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1996; 19: 463-489Crossref PubMed Scopus (908) Google Scholar). Although an indispensable role for Ras in mediating NGF-promoted neuronal differentiation and survival has been convincingly demonstrated using function blocking anti-Ras antibodies as well as by dominant negative or constitutively active Ras mutants (9Noda M. Ko M. Ogura A. Liu D.G. Amano T. Takano T. Ikawa Y. Nature. 1985; 318: 73-75Crossref PubMed Scopus (350) Google Scholar, 10Bar-Sagi D. Feramisco J.R. Cell. 1985; 42: 841-848Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (569) Google Scholar, 11Szeberenyi J. Cai H. Cooper G.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 5324-5332Crossref PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 12Borasio G.D. Markus A. Wittinghofer A. Barde Y.A. Heumann R. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 665-672Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar), the time course of mSOS1-dependent Ras activation in fact exhibits a profile of activation lasting 4–5 h followed by a gradual decline in activity to near-basal level within 24 h (13Qui M.S. Green S.H. Neuron. 1992; 9: 705-717Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (360) Google Scholar). The latter observation contrasts with the finding that NGF is required at all times to provide long term trophic support and to maintain neuronal PC12 cells in a differentiated state (6Greene L.A. J. Cell Biol. 1978; 78: 747-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). The temporal dichotomy between the transient initial signaling events and chronic NGF dependence raises the possibility that alternative mechanisms might exist to maintain Ras activation necessary for long term NGF responsiveness. Initially identified as an endothelial cell relaxing factor, nitric oxide (NO) has since been demonstrated to mediate a variety of cellular functions in the nervous system as well as in non-neuronal tissues (14Bredt D.S. Snyder S.H. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 175-195Crossref PubMed Scopus (2147) Google Scholar,15Nelson R.J. Kriegsfeld L.J. Dawson V.L. Dawson T.M. Front Neuroendocrinol. 1997; 18: 463-491Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Protein targets whose activities are altered by NO, including the NMDA receptor (16Lipton S.A. Choi Y.B. Pan Z.H. Lei S.Z. Chen H.S. Sucher N.J. Loscalzo J. Singel D.J. Stamler J.S. Nature. 1993; 364: 626-632Crossref PubMed Scopus (2309) Google Scholar), JAK2 (17Duhe R.J. Evans G.A. Erwin R.A. Kirken R.A. Cox G.W. Farrar W.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 126-131Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar), and caspase-3 (18Kim Y.M. Kim T.H. Seol D.W. Talanian R.V. Billiar T.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 31437-31441Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar), are diverse regulators of cellular homeostasis. Using electrospray-ionization mass spectrometry, we have previously shown that NO directly interacts with and activates Ras via S-nitrosylation on a single cysteine (Cys-118) residue (19Lander H.M. Milbank A.J. Tauras J.M. Hajjar D.P. Hempstead B.L. Schwartz G.D. Kraemer R.T. Mirza U.A. Chait B.T. Burk S.C. Quilliam L.A. Nature. 1996; 381: 380-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). Additional findings suggest that NO-activated Ras can recruit the downstream effectors Raf-1 and PI 3-kinase, independent of mSOS1-Ras binding (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). Because the interaction between mSOS1 and Ras can be rapidly down-regulated by an ERK-dependent negative feedback (21Buday L. Warne P.H. Downward J. Oncogene. 1995; 11: 1327-1331PubMed Google Scholar, 22Corbalan-Garcia S. Yang S.S. Degenhardt K.R. Bar-Sagi D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 5674-5682Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar), NO-mediated Ras activation might be a physiological mechanism for maintaining Ras function in specific cell types that synthesize NO in response to growth factor treatment. Of particular relevance to the present work, neuronal differentiation of PC12 cells is accompanied by up-regulation of nitric-oxide synthase (NOS), leading to sustained NO release (23Peunova N. Enikolopov G. Nature. 1995; 375: 68-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar,24Poluha W. Schonhoff C.M. Harrington K.S. Lachyankar M.B. Crosbie N.E. Bulseco D.A. Ross A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24002-24007Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Using this NGF-responsive cellular paradigm, we show here that long term neuronal survival, but not differentiation, requires the activation of Ras by NO. RasWtPC12 or RasC118SPC12 cells were generated from parental PC12 cells by transfection with either the c-Ha-Ras or RasC118Sencoding cDNA subcloned into the mammalian expression vector pcDNA3 as described previously (25Teng K.K. Lander H. Fajardo J.E. Hanafusa H. Hempstead B.L. Birge R.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 20677-20685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). G418-resistant PC12 subclones expressing RasWt or RasC118S protein were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 400 μg of G418/ml/5% horse serum/10% calf serum. For neuronal differentiation and cell death measurements, cells were plated at low densities (e.g. 5 × 105 cells/35-mm collagen-coated dish) in 2% calf serum and 1% horse serum in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium plus 100 ng/ml recombinant mouse 2.5 S NGF (Harlan Bioproducts for Science). For other experiments, cells were plated at higher densities (e.g. 1 × 106 cells per 35-mm collagen-coated dish), providing adequate material for biochemical analysis. Higher serum concentrations in the culture medium or 2–3-fold variation in plating density did not significantly affect the death of NGF-treated RasC118SPC12 cells. 2K. K. Teng, unpublished observation. Equal amounts of protein (2.0 mg) from detergent lysates were immunoprecipitated with either agarose-conjugated anti-Ras antibody Y13–238 or Y13–259 (both from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, used at 15 μl/sample), followed by Western immunoblotting analysis using ECL reagents (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) as described (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). The Y13–238 antibody was utilized for demonstrating mSOS1 and Raf-1 co-immunoprecipitation with Ras. Although the Y13–259 antibody has been reported to prevent complex formation between activated Ras and PI 3-kinase (26Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Dhand R. Vanhaesebroeck B. Gout I. Fry M.J. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. Nature. 1994; 370: 527-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (1731) Google Scholar), this antibody does not appear to disrupt preformed Ras-PI 3-kinase complexes (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar, 27Foschi M. Chari S. Dunn M.J. Sorokin A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6439-6451Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). Control experiments, however, confirmed that Y13–259 does disrupt pre-formed Ras-Raf-1 complexes.2 For Western blotting analysis, the following commerically available antibodies were used: polyclonal anti-Raf-1, anti-mSOS1, and anti-p110β antisera were from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, anti-Ras monoclonal antibody AB-2 was from Oncogene Research Products, and the anti-phosphotyrosine monoclonal antibodies PY20 and 4G10 were from Transduction Laboratory and UBI, respectively. All antibodies were used at 1:1000 dilution except PY20 and 4G10, which were used at 1:5000 dilution. For PI 3-kinase assay, equal amounts (1.5 mg) of detergent lysates were immunoprecipitated with either the anti-phosphotyrosine antibody 4G10 (used at 4 μl/sample) or the agarose-conjugated anti-Ras antibody Y13–259 as described (27Foschi M. Chari S. Dunn M.J. Sorokin A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6439-6451Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar) with the following modifications. Immunoprecipitates were washed twice with lysis buffer (27Foschi M. Chari S. Dunn M.J. Sorokin A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6439-6451Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar), once with 0.5 mLiCl, 100 mm Tris·HCl, pH 7.5, once with 0.5% Triton X-100, 30 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, and once with distilled water before the kinase assay. MAP kinase assays were performed from detergent lysates immunoprecipitated with a mixture of anti-ERK1 and ERK2 antisera (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, both used at 2 μl/sample) as described (25Teng K.K. Lander H. Fajardo J.E. Hanafusa H. Hempstead B.L. Birge R.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 20677-20685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar) using [γ-32P] ATP and myelin basic protein as a substrate. The results for both MAP kinase and PI 3-kinase assays were quantified by PhosphorImager analysis (Molecular Dynamics). Additional standard biochemical procedures were followed as referenced. We generated PC12 cell lines that stably express a Ras mutant protein in which the cysteine at position 118 has been mutated to serine (RasC118S, Fig. 1 A), a point mutation that renders this molecule nonresponsive to NO (19Lander H.M. Milbank A.J. Tauras J.M. Hajjar D.P. Hempstead B.L. Schwartz G.D. Kraemer R.T. Mirza U.A. Chait B.T. Burk S.C. Quilliam L.A. Nature. 1996; 381: 380-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). As a control, PC12 cells that stably express the wild type c-Ha-Ras (RasWt) at comparable levels were also generated. Expression of RasC118S and RasWt at significant levels (7–10-fold more than endogenous Ras) in each of the PC12 transfectants (referred to as RasC118SPC12 and RasWtPC12 cells, respectively) per se did not affect proliferation or overall viability. Because the mSOS1-dependent pathway for Ras activation is a critical early event in NGF signaling (4Greene L.A. Kaplan D.R. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 579-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 5Segal R.A. Greenberg M.E. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1996; 19: 463-489Crossref PubMed Scopus (908) Google Scholar), we first examined whether RasC118S expression might perturb such an interaction. Western blot analysis of anti-Ras immunoprecipitates revealed that overexpression of either RasWt and RasC118Sleads to enhanced co-immunoprecipitation with endogenous mSOS1 (Fig. 1 B). Furthermore, using GTP loading assay as a measurement of Ras activation (Fig. 1 C), RasC118S was found to be activated by NGF to an extent comparable with RasWt. These data indicate that, in contrast to other Ras mutants that interfere with guanine nucleotide exchange (28Kjeldgaard M. Nyborg J. Clark B.F. FASEB J. 1996; 10: 1347-1368Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar), the C118S mutation in Ras does not affect the interaction with upstream GEFs necessary for its activation. Consistent with this interpretation, a prior in vitro study has concluded that Cys-118 is not a critical residue for basal GDP-GTP exchange (28Kjeldgaard M. Nyborg J. Clark B.F. FASEB J. 1996; 10: 1347-1368Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar, 29Mott H.R. Carpenter J.W. Campbell S.L. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 3640-3644Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Next, the integrity of early NGF-induced signaling cascade in RasC118S-expressing PC12 cells was examined. As anticipated, signaling components that lie upstream of Ras are not altered by RasWt or RasC118S expression whereas the NGF induced activation of the downstream MAP kinase cascade is enhanced in both RasWtPC12 and RasC118SPC12 cells. Time course comparison of NGF-triggered signaling events by anti-phosphotyrosine immunoblotting analysis revealed comparable kinetics of tyrosine phosphorylation of Shc (30Rozakis-Adcock M. McGlade J. Mbamalu G. Pelicci G. Daly R. Li W. Batzer A. Thomas S. Brugge J. Pelicci P.G. Schlessinger J. Pawson T. Nature. 1992; 360: 689-692Crossref PubMed Scopus (828) Google Scholar) (e.g.52-kDa Shc) with augmented activation of the MAP kinases in both the RasWt-and RasC118S-expressing PC12 cells (Fig. 1 D). Immunoprecipitation-MAP kinase assay also confirmed a 2-fold enhancement of NGF-activated MAP kinase activity in both the RasWtPC12 and RasC118SPC12 cells when compared with that in the parental PC12 cells (data not shown). However, the observation that mutation of Cys-118 to Ser in Ras abrogates NO responsiveness in vitro (19Lander H.M. Milbank A.J. Tauras J.M. Hajjar D.P. Hempstead B.L. Schwartz G.D. Kraemer R.T. Mirza U.A. Chait B.T. Burk S.C. Quilliam L.A. Nature. 1996; 381: 380-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar) suggests that RasC118S might be a null mutant specific for NO-induced activation in intact cells (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). To address this hypothesis, we measured total cellular Ras activity in RasWtPC12 and RasC118SPC12 cells treated with the NO donor sodium nitroprusside (SNP). The analysis was performed in cells that have been pretreated with NGF for 7 days because (i) PC12 cells synthesize NO only upon long term NGF-induced neuronal differentiation (23Peunova N. Enikolopov G. Nature. 1995; 375: 68-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar, 24Poluha W. Schonhoff C.M. Harrington K.S. Lachyankar M.B. Crosbie N.E. Bulseco D.A. Ross A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24002-24007Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar), and (ii) nitrosylation of protein targets can be modulated by intracellular redox status (31Aleryani S. Milo E. Rose Y. Kostka P. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 6041-6045Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), which is altered after NGF treatment (32Pan Z. Perez-Polo R. J. Neurochem. 1993; 61: 1713-1721Crossref PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 1 E, 15 min of SNP treatment leads to an approximately 40% increase in basal Ras activity in PC12 cells that overexpressed RasWt. In contrast, RasC118SPC12 cells are not responsive to exogenous NO, even though comparable NGF-induced Ras activation (>4-fold over basal level) can be achieved via the mSOS1-dependent mechanism (Fig. 1, B andC). In the absence of NGF, both RasWt- and RasC118S-expressing PC12 cells display an undifferentiated phenotype with occasional short cytoplasmic extensions of less than one cell body diameter in length. Upon NGF treatment, RasC118SPC12 cells undergo morphological differentiation with neurite extension that is characteristic of parental PC12 cells (7Greene L.A. Tischler A.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1976; 73: 2424-2428Crossref PubMed Scopus (4873) Google Scholar) (Fig. 2 A). However, in support of a role for the Ras-MAP kinase pathway in mediating the differentiative action of NGF, both RasWtPC12 and RasC118SPC12 cells exhibit enhanced neuritogenic responsiveness to NGF (Fig. 2 C). Together these results and those obtained from additional independently generated Ras-expressing cell lines establish that RasC118S functions indistinguishably from RasWt in augmenting the well characterized signaling events that are pertinent to neuronal differentiation (4Greene L.A. Kaplan D.R. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 579-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 5Segal R.A. Greenberg M.E. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1996; 19: 463-489Crossref PubMed Scopus (908) Google Scholar). When treated for prolonged periods with NGF (>5 days), however, the RasC118S-expressing PC12 cells begin to degenerate and exhibit morphological signs of cell death where phase-dark cell bodies and pyknotic nuclei are frequently observed and pre-existing neurites have degenerated (Fig. 2 A). In addition, chromatin condensation (Fig. 2 B; Hoechst 33258 staining) and DNA strand breaks (Fig. 2 D; TdT-mediated dUTP nick end-labeling (TUNEL) analysis) are apparent in dying RasC118SPC12 cells, indicating that this form of cell death is apoptotic (33Xia Z. Dickens M. Raingeaud J. Davis R.J. Greenberg M.E. Science. 1995; 270: 1326-1331Crossref PubMed Scopus (5045) Google Scholar). At all time points examined, comparably treated parental PC12 or RasWtPC12 cells appeared healthy with intact nuclei and extensive neurite networks. A comparison between the time course of neurite initiation (Fig. 2 C) with the onset of cell death (Fig. 2 D) further suggests that neuronal differentiation precedes RasC118SPC12 cell apoptosis. Consistent with this interpretation, long term treatment (>7 days) of RasC118SPC12 cells with basic fibroblast growth factor, which induces neuronal differentiation (34Rydel R.E. Greene L.A. J. Neurosci. 1987; 7: 3639-3653Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), but not the mitogenic epidermal growth factor (35Mutoh T. Rudkin B.B. Koizumi S. Guroff G. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 15853-15856Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), also results in apoptotic cell death (data not shown). Previous studies have shown that long term NGF treatment of PC12 cells leads to the up-regulation of NOS activity with kinetics that are tightly coupled to the onset of neuronal differentiation (23Peunova N. Enikolopov G. Nature. 1995; 375: 68-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar). Using cellular diaphorase staining, which is a histochemical marker for NOS-positive neurons (36Dawson T.M. Bredt D.S. Fotuhi M. Hwang P.M. Snyder S.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 7797-7801Crossref PubMed Scopus (1841) Google Scholar), and PC12 cells (23Peunova N. Enikolopov G. Nature. 1995; 375: 68-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar, 24Poluha W. Schonhoff C.M. Harrington K.S. Lachyankar M.B. Crosbie N.E. Bulseco D.A. Ross A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24002-24007Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar), we confirmed this observation in PC12 cells and found that NOS activity is not inhibited by RasWt or RasC118S expression (data not shown). Because the only detectable difference between RasWt and RasC118S is that the latter cannot be activated by NO, we postulated that high levels of RasC118Sexpression may interfere with endogenous NO-responsive Ras to modulate downstream signaling pathways that are critical for survival (26Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Dhand R. Vanhaesebroeck B. Gout I. Fry M.J. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. Nature. 1994; 370: 527-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (1731) Google Scholar, 33Xia Z. Dickens M. Raingeaud J. Davis R.J. Greenberg M.E. Science. 1995; 270: 1326-1331Crossref PubMed Scopus (5045) Google Scholar,37Warne P.H. Viciana P.R. Downward J. Nature. 1993; 364: 352-355Crossref PubMed Scopus (584) Google Scholar, 38Yao R. Cooper G.M. Science. 1995; 267: 2003-2006Crossref PubMed Scopus (1295) Google Scholar). Apoptosis of a variety of cell types, including PC12 cells, has been causally linked to the down-regulation of the anti-apoptotic MAP kinase ERK (33Xia Z. Dickens M. Raingeaud J. Davis R.J. Greenberg M.E. Science. 1995; 270: 1326-1331Crossref PubMed Scopus (5045) Google Scholar) and PI 3-kinase (38Yao R. Cooper G.M. Science. 1995; 267: 2003-2006Crossref PubMed Scopus (1295) Google Scholar). Interestingly, both kinases are downstream targets of Ras (26Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Dhand R. Vanhaesebroeck B. Gout I. Fry M.J. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. Nature. 1994; 370: 527-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (1731) Google Scholar, 37Warne P.H. Viciana P.R. Downward J. Nature. 1993; 364: 352-355Crossref PubMed Scopus (584) Google Scholar). To assess whether the coupling of either effector to Ras is impaired by RasC118S expression, we first compared the Ras-Raf-1 interaction and activity of MAP kinases in long term (≥7 days) NGF-treated RasC118SPC12 and RasWtPC12 cells. However, no detectable differences were observed between these two cell types as both display comparable Ras-Raf-1 interaction (Fig. 3 A) and MAP kinase activation (Fig. 3 B). Significantly, dying RasC118SPC12 cells continue to exhibit enhanced Raf-1-mediated MAP kinase activation when compared with parental PC12 cells (Fig. 3, A andB). Although PI 3-kinase can be activated by binding to tyrosine-phosphorylated sequences and by direct interaction with Ras (39Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Vanhaesebroeck B. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 2442-2451Crossref PubMed Scopus (501) Google Scholar), the relative contribution of these two activation pathways on PI 3-kinase in long term NGF-treated PC12 cells has not been examined. We found that, in contrast to the Ras-Raf-1 interaction (Fig. 3 A), RasWt overexpression does not result in increased p110β binding or PI 3-kinase activation (when compared with the parental PC12 cells; Fig. 3, C and D). This suggests that additional mechanism(s) might limit the extent of Ras-dependent PI 3-kinase activation in neuronal PC12 cells (see “Discussion” below). Most importantly, however, immunoprecipitation-Western blot analysis reveals that although comparable PI 3-kinase p110β subunit expression was present in all three cell types and in the anti-phosphotyrosine immunoprecipitates, RasC118S fails to interact with PI 3-kinase in long term NGF-treated RasC118SPC12 cells (Fig. 3 C). Consistent with the co-immunoprecipitation results, we also found a significant decline (>50%) in Ras-associated PI 3-kinase activity in long term NGF-treated RasC118SPC12 cells whereas the kinase activity in the anti-phosphotyrosine immunoprecipitates remains unaffected (Fig. 3 D). Together the above findings establish that expression of the RasC118S mutant protein may cause apoptosis of NGF-differentiated PC12 cells by affecting the Ras-PI 3-kinase pathway critical for cell survival (26Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Dhand R. Vanhaesebroeck B. Gout I. Fry M.J. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. Nature. 1994; 370: 527-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (1731) Google Scholar, 38Yao R. Cooper G.M. Science. 1995; 267: 2003-2006Crossref PubMed Scopus (1295) Google Scholar, 40Dudek H. Datta S.R. Franke T.F. Birnbaum M.J. Yao R. Cooper G.M. Segal R.A. Kaplan D.R. Greenberg M.E. Science. 1997; 275: 661-665Crossref PubMed Scopus (2222) Google Scholar). Interestingly, RasC118S does not interfere with, and in fact enhances, the cascade of differentiative signaling events and is “pro-apoptotic” only after PC12 cells have acquired a neuronal phenotype. The observation that expression of either RasWt or the RasC118S leads to augmented MAP kinase activation suggests that maintaining MAP kinase activity in neuronal PC12 cells is a GEF-dependent, but NO-independent, process. In contrast, the specific decrease in Ras-mediated PI 3-kinase activation and RasC118SPC12 cell death is particularly significant and implicates a causal relationship (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar, 26Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Dhand R. Vanhaesebroeck B. Gout I. Fry M.J. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. Nature. 1994; 370: 527-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (1731) Google Scholar, 38Yao R. Cooper G.M. Science. 1995; 267: 2003-2006Crossref PubMed Scopus (1295) Google Scholar). These observations suggest a model in which NGF evokes at least two distinct mechanisms for Ras activation culminating in unique biochemical and biological outputs: the well characterized mSOS1-Ras-Raf-1 pathway required for differentiative signaling (4Greene L.A. Kaplan D.R. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 579-587Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 5Segal R.A. Greenberg M.E. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1996; 19: 463-489Crossref PubMed Scopus (908) Google Scholar) and the latent NO-mediated Ras-PI 3-kinase cascade regulating cell survival. It has been reported that optimal PI 3-kinase activation by Ras occurs when the p85α subunit-binding phosphotyrosine peptide is present at suboptimal concentrations (39Rodriguez-Viciana P. Warne P.H. Vanhaesebroeck B. Waterfield M.D. Downward J. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 2442-2451Crossref PubMed Scopus (501) Google Scholar). Therefore, at a time when most early NGF-inducible tyrosine phosphorylation events have returned to near basal levels (i.e. in neuronally differentiated PC12 cells), the NO-Ras interaction may be the predominant activating mechanism for PI 3-kinase. Currently we do not fully understand how NO synthesis is coupled to endogenous Ras-PI 3-kinase activation, or conversely, how ectopic expression of RasC118S interferes with this process. However, several potential models merit consideration. First, RasC118S might behave as an effector site mutant specifically impaired in PI 3-kinase binding (41Kauffmann-Zeh A. Rodriguez-Viciana P. Ulrich E. Gilbert C. Coffer P. Downward J. Evan G. Nature. 1997; 385: 544-548Crossref PubMed Scopus (1075) Google Scholar), but available information on Ras-effector interaction, which emphasizes residues flanking the switch I region of Ras (41Kauffmann-Zeh A. Rodriguez-Viciana P. Ulrich E. Gilbert C. Coffer P. Downward J. Evan G. Nature. 1997; 385: 544-548Crossref PubMed Scopus (1075) Google Scholar, 42Vojtek A.B. Der C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19925-19928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (499) Google Scholar), argues against this possibility. Second, because NO (or other higher reactive nitrogen species) exists as short-lived free radical (43Stamler J.S. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1995; 196: 19-36Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar), a scaffolding molecule, such as caveolin (44Garcia-Cardena G. Martasek P. Masters B.S. Skidd P.M. Couet J. Li S. Lisanti M.P. Sessa W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 25437-25440Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (696) Google Scholar, 45Song S.K. Li S. Okamoto T. Quilliam L.A. Sargiacomo M. Lisanti M.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 9690-9697Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (921) Google Scholar), might sequester NOS and Ras within physical proximity for efficient signal transduction. Recently, a multidomain Ras-binding protein SUR-8/SOC-2 has been identified inCaenorhabditis elegans that serves to modulate the Raf-1 signaling (46Therrien M. Wong A.M. Rubin G.M. Cell. 1998; 95: 343-353Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). Although speculative at present, it is conceivable that SUR-8/SOC-2 or other similar Ras-binding proteins might also enhance PI 3-kinase activity. High levels of RasC118S expression would terminate NO signaling by displacing endogenous Ras from either the “scaffold” or the “enhancer,” thereby conferring the observed dominant inhibitory phenotype on PI 3-kinase activation. Limited expression of such a molecule(s) would also explain why RasWt overexpression does not further activate PI 3-kinase (Fig. 3, C andD). Experiments are in progress to specifically address these possibilities. In summary we have identified a novel mechanism for maintaining distinct cellular responses via a common signaling intermediate. It has been proposed that, similar to phosphorylation, protein nitrosylation is a sequence-specific, reversible, covalent modification event (47Stamler J.S. Tooner E.J. Lipton S.A. Sucher N.J. Neuron. 1997; 18: 691-696Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (621) Google Scholar). Although nitrosothiol formation is suggested here to play a critical role in sustaining neuronal PC12 cell survival via PI 3-kinase, NO-dependent modulation of Ras functions can be extended to non-neuronal paradigms (48Lander H.M. Ogiste J.S. Teng K.K. Novogrodsky A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 21195-21198Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar) and might activate the Raf-1-MAP kinase pathway instead (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar, 49Yun H.Y. Gonzalez-Zulueta M. Dawson V.L. Dawson T.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 5773-5778Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar). Our prior study has demonstrated that Ras can also be activated by reactive oxygen species (48Lander H.M. Ogiste J.S. Teng K.K. Novogrodsky A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 21195-21198Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar), suggesting that Ras activation might be modulated by a stimulus (e.g.platelet-derived growth factor) or pathway (e.g. activated Rac) that generates reactive oxygen intermediates (50Sundaresan M. Yu Z.X. Ferrans V.J. Irani K. Finkel T. Science. 1995; 270: 296-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (2321) Google Scholar, 51Irani K. Xia Y. Zweier J.L. Sollott S.J. Der C.J. Fearon E.R. Sundaresan M. Finkel T. Goldschmidt-Clermont P.J. Science. 1997; 275: 1649-1652Crossref PubMed Scopus (1441) Google Scholar). Intriguingly, the Cys-118 on Ras, although dispensable for GEF binding (28Kjeldgaard M. Nyborg J. Clark B.F. FASEB J. 1996; 10: 1347-1368Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar) (this study), is conserved within subfamily members of the Ras GTPase superfamily. Thus molecules such as Rap1 and Rab3 might be subjected to analogous modification with unique downstream consequences. A future research challenge will be to assign the pleiotropic effects of free radical signaling to individual small GTPases. We thank Sharon Campbell for the RasWt and RasC118S cDNA and Moses Chao and Patrizia Casaccia-Bonnefil for helpful discussions.

Designing altered peptide ligands to generate specific immunological reactivity when bound to class I major histocompatibility complexes is important for both therapeutic and prophylactic reasons. We have previously shown that two altered peptides, derived from human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-reverse transcriptase (RT) residues 309–317, are more immunogenic in vitro than the wild-type peptide. One peptide variant, I1Y, was able to stimulate RT-specific cytotoxic T cells from the blood of three HIV-infected individuals better than the wild-type RT peptide. Both I1Y and I1F peptide variants increase the cell surface half-life of the peptide-class I complex approximately 3-fold over that of the RT peptide but have different immunological activities. These peptides are candidates for the design of vaccines for HIV due to their increased immunogenicity. To understand the basis for the increased cell surface stability compared with wild-type peptide and to understand the differences in T cell recognition between I1Y and I1F, we determined the x-ray crystal structures of the two class I MHC-peptide complexes. These structures indicate that the increased cell surface half-life is due to π-π stacking interactions between Trp-167 of HLA-A2.1 and the aromatic P1 residues of I1F and I1Y. Comparison of the structures and modeling potential T cell receptor (TCR) interactions suggests that T cell interactions and immunogenicity are different between I1Y and I1F for two reasons. First, subtle changes in the steric and polar properties of the I1Y peptide affect TCR engagement. Second, water-mediated hydrogen bond interactions between the P1-Tyr and the P4-Glu peptide residues increase peptide side chain rigidity of residues critical for TCR engagement. Designing altered peptide ligands to generate specific immunological reactivity when bound to class I major histocompatibility complexes is important for both therapeutic and prophylactic reasons. We have previously shown that two altered peptides, derived from human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-reverse transcriptase (RT) residues 309–317, are more immunogenic in vitro than the wild-type peptide. One peptide variant, I1Y, was able to stimulate RT-specific cytotoxic T cells from the blood of three HIV-infected individuals better than the wild-type RT peptide. Both I1Y and I1F peptide variants increase the cell surface half-life of the peptide-class I complex approximately 3-fold over that of the RT peptide but have different immunological activities. These peptides are candidates for the design of vaccines for HIV due to their increased immunogenicity. To understand the basis for the increased cell surface stability compared with wild-type peptide and to understand the differences in T cell recognition between I1Y and I1F, we determined the x-ray crystal structures of the two class I MHC-peptide complexes. These structures indicate that the increased cell surface half-life is due to π-π stacking interactions between Trp-167 of HLA-A2.1 and the aromatic P1 residues of I1F and I1Y. Comparison of the structures and modeling potential T cell receptor (TCR) interactions suggests that T cell interactions and immunogenicity are different between I1Y and I1F for two reasons. First, subtle changes in the steric and polar properties of the I1Y peptide affect TCR engagement. Second, water-mediated hydrogen bond interactions between the P1-Tyr and the P4-Glu peptide residues increase peptide side chain rigidity of residues critical for TCR engagement. T cell receptor reverse transcriptase major histocompatibility complex human immunodeficiency virus cytotoxic T lymphocytes peripheral blood lymphocytes 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid non-crystallographic-symmetry root mean square The cytolytic immune response is a major component of the body's defense against viral infection (1Doherty P.C. Allan W. Eichelberger M. Carding S.R. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1992; 10: 123-151Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). This response is mediated by the interaction between the T cell receptor (TCR)1 on CD8+cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and the class I major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules expressed on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (2Zinkernagel R.M. Doherty P.C. Nature. 1974; 248: 701-702Crossref PubMed Scopus (1448) Google Scholar). Control of viral infections such as HIV requires a vigorous CTL response (3Schmitz J.E. Kuroda M.J. Santra S. Sasseville V.G. Simon M.A. Lifton M.A. Racz P. Tenner-Racz K. Dalesandro M. Scallon B.J. Ghrayeb J. Forman M.A. Montefiori D.C. Rieber E.P. Letvin N.L. Reimann K.A. Science. 1999; 283: 857-860Crossref PubMed Scopus (1962) Google Scholar). Class I MHC molecules are trimolecular complexes consisting of an allotype-specific heavy chain, a light chain β2-microglobulin, and an endogenously processed peptide. The antigenic peptide typically binds with the termini buried in the peptide-binding cleft. The middle of the peptide frequently bulges out of the peptide-binding cleft. Bulging in the center makes these residues more accessible to the TCR and as such these residues are usually critical for TCR recognition (see Ref. 4Batalia M.A. Collins E.J. Biopolymers. 1997; 43: 281-302Crossref PubMed Google Scholar for review). Class I MHC molecules are capable of binding a diverse set of peptides with long half-lives. A major component of the binding energy is derived from interactions between conserved residues in the peptide-binding cleft and the invariant peptidic termini (5Madden D.R. Garboczi D.N. Wiley D.C. Cell. 1993; 75: 693-708Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar). Additionally, peptides that bind with high affinity typically have two or more relatively invariant residues, termed anchors, that bind in specificity pockets primarily composed of class I heavy chain polymorphic residues (6Jardetzky T.S. Lane W.S. Robinson R.A. Madden D.R. Wiley D.C. Nature. 1991; 353: 326-329Crossref PubMed Scopus (735) Google Scholar, 7Hunt D.F. Henderson R.A. Shabanowitz J. Sakaguchi K. Michel H. Sevilir N. Cox A.L. Appella E. Engelhard V.H. Science. 1992; 255: 1261-1263Crossref PubMed Scopus (1060) Google Scholar, 8Falk K. Rotzschke O. Stevanovic S. Jung G. Rammensee H.G. Nature. 1991; 351: 290-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (2132) Google Scholar). Other positions in the peptide can also make significant contributions to peptide-MHC affinity (9Ruppert J. Sidney J. Celis E. Kubo R.T. Grey H.M. Sette A. Cell. 1993; 74: 929-937Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (620) Google Scholar). Previously, we identified two aromatic single amino acid substitutions at the amino-terminal end (P1 position, normally isoleucine) of the HLA-A2.1 (A2)-restricted HIV reverse transcriptase (RT) peptide-(309–317) (ILKEPVHGV) that increase the cell surface half-lives of complexes 3-fold over the A2/RT-peptide complex. These two peptides, designated I1F and I1Y, also show increased immunogenicity compared with the wild-type RT. In vitroexperiments with peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBLs) from three different HIV-positive patients show that in vitro expansion of CTL using I1Y-pulsed antigen-presenting cells stimulates a higher CTL response against wild-type RT-pulsed target cells than in vitro expansion with the RT peptide itself. In contrast, I1F-pulsed cells stimulate a higher response against RT-pulsed cells in only one of the two sets of donor PBLs that were tested. The I1F and I1Y peptides also differ in their ability to be recognized by RT-specific CTL lines (10Pogue R.R. Eron J. Frelinger J.A. Matsui M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 8166-8170Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). To understand better why the I1Y, I1F, and RT peptides have differing immunological properties, we determined the x-ray crystal structures of A2 complexed with I1Y and I1F peptides to 2.2 and 2.8 Å resolution, respectively. Comparison of these structures with the previously determined RT structure (5Madden D.R. Garboczi D.N. Wiley D.C. Cell. 1993; 75: 693-708Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar), along with modeling the interactions of the A6 and B7 TCRs (11Garboczi D.N. Ghosh P. Utz U. Fan Q.R. Biddison W.E. Wiley D.C. Nature. 1996; 384: 134-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (1212) Google Scholar, 12Ding Y.H. Smith K.J. Garboczi D.N. Utz U. Biddison W.E. Wiley D.C. Immunity. 1998; 8: 403-411Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar) with the three A2 structures, has given us insight into the differing immunological properties. The crystallographic structures suggest that the increases in cell surface half-life are due to interactions between the aromatic P1 residues (Tyr and Phe) and tryptophan-167 of A2. Pseudo homology models of TCR and these class I MHC complexes suggest that the differences in T cell recognition between the I1Y and I1F complexes may be attributed to two subtle structural differences due specifically to the hydroxyl group of P1-tyrosine. All peptides were synthesized by the Peptide Synthesis Facility at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. The sequences of the peptides are ILKEPVHGV (wild-type RT), YLKEPVHGV (I1Y), and FLKEPVHGV (I1F). All peptides were purified by reverse-phase high pressure liquid chromatography to greater than 95% purity, and the sequences were confirmed by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight spectrometry. A2/I1Y and A2/I1F complexes were folded by rapid dilution in vitro as described previously (13Garboczi D.N. Hung D.T. Wiley D.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 3233-3429Crossref Scopus (567) Google Scholar). After incubation for 36–48 h at 10 °C, the folding solutions were concentrated in an ultrafiltration cell (Amicon; Beverly, MA) and purified by high pressure liquid chromatography-gel filtration chromatography (Phenomenex, BioSep-SEC-S2000) in 50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl. Purified complexes were then concentrated using Centricon-10 concentrators (Amicon) and exchanged into buffers consisting of either 25 mm MES, pH 6.5, for crystallization, or 10 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7.4, for circular dichroism experiments. The relative stabilities of the peptide/A2 complexes were measured by circular dichroism (CD) thermal denaturation experiments. The experiments were performed on an AVIV 62-DS spectropolarimeter equipped with a Peltier temperature control unit. The protein concentration was approximately 10 μm in 10 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7.4. The thermal denaturation of purified A2/RT, A2/I1Y, and A2/I1F complexes was monitored as the change in circular dichroic signal at 218 nm from 4 to 95 °C. The T m values (50% denatured) were determined by modeling the denaturation as a two-state process (14Bouvier M. Wiley D.C. Science. 1994; 265: 398-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar) from a normalized plot of the denaturation. The reportedT m is the average of three separate thermal denaturation experiments. The error associated with the reportedT m is the sum of the machine error (0.5 °C) and the error in the curve fit (∼0.5 °C). Both A2/I1Y and A2/I1F complexes were crystallized by the hanging drop vapor-diffusion method. The well solution for A2/I1Y contained 18% PEG-8000 in 25 mm MES, pH 6.5, and the hanging drop was a 1:1 mixture of the well solution and 10 mg/ml protein in 25 mm MES, pH 6.5. The well solution for A2/I1F contained 20% PEG-8000 in 25 mm MES, pH 6., and the hanging drop was a 1:1 mixture of the well solution and 10 mg/ml protein in 25 mm MES, pH 6.5. Microseeding was performed for both complexes to obtain large single crystals suitable for crystallographic studies. Crystals were transferred directly into cryoprotectant buffer containing 20% PEG-8000 supplemented with 25–30% glycerol in 25 mm MES, pH 6.5, and placed directly into a 100 K nitrogen stream generated by an Oxford Cryo System. The A2/I1Y diffraction data were collected on beamline X-12B at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS), Brookhaven National Laboratories (Upton, NY). The A2/I1F diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku R-Axis IIC using CuKα radiation. All diffraction data were processed using the programs Denzo and Scalepack (15Otwinowski Z. Minor W. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 276: 307-326Crossref Scopus (38617) Google Scholar). Chem. 1991; 47: 110-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (13014) Google Scholar). Computational refinement was performed using the programs X-PLOR version 3.851 (19Brunger A. X-PLOR, A System for X-ray Crystallography and NMR, Version 3.1. Yale University Press, New Haven, CT1992Google Scholar) and Refmac (20Murshudov G.N. Vagin A.A. Dodson E.J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Struct. Sci. 1997; 53: 240-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (13914) Google Scholar) in CCP4 (21Dodson E.J. Winn M. Ralph A. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 277: 620-633Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar). The structure was first refined in X-PLOR using 8–2.2-Å resolution data. Two-fold non-crystallographic-symmetry (NCS) restraints were applied to the two molecules in the asymmetric unit of A2/I1Y crystals with a weight of 300 kcal mol−1Å−2. Overall isotropic B factor refinement was first performed, followed by rigid body refinement using three structural domains as follows: α1/α2 (the peptide-binding superdomain), α3, and β2-microglobulin. Cycles of computational refinement were performed using positional refinement. Later cycles of refinement were performed using Refmac with “strict” NCS restraints (see Refmac manual), a bulk solvent correction, overall anisotropic B factor correction, and individual B factor refinement. 192 water molecules were added to the structure using program ARP (22Lamzin V.S. Wilson K.S. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 277: 269-305Crossref PubMed Scopus (278) Google Scholar) in CCP4 with Refmac as the refinement tool. The final R free (23Brunger A.T. Nature. 1992; 355: 472-474Crossref PubMed Scopus (3872) Google Scholar) andR work factors (F >0) between 30 and 2.2 Å are 28.9 and 24.4%, respectively. The refinement statistics are shown in Table I. The conformations of the peptides were confirmed by the following “averaged” omit map procedure. The peptide was omitted from the refined model before calculation of the phases and structure factors used to generate the electron density map input into DM. Model masks were made using peptide to be sure that all averaging included peptide regions. Finally, model phase bias was reduced from the initial map in DM by 2-fold non-crystallographic averaging, solvent flattening, and histogram matching. Refinement of A2/I1F was performed as was A2/I1Y except Refmac was used throughout the refinement. Rigid body refinement was used to optimize the domain positions. Cycles of positional refinement were performed with strict NCS restraints (see Refmac manual), a bulk solvent correction, overall anisotropic B factor correction, and overall temperature factor refinement. Final cycles included individual temperature factor refinement. This was justified by the observation of a drop in the R free. The final R free and R workfactors (F >0) between 15 and 2.8 Å are 31.5 and 27.4%, respectively. The refinement statistics are shown in Table I. The thermal stability of class I MHC molecules, as measured by circular dichroism (CD), is proportional to the free energy of peptide binding (24Morgan C.S. Holton J.M. Olafson B.D. Bjorkman P.J. Mayo S.L. Protein Sci. 1997; 6: 1771-1773Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). We used CD thermal denaturation experiments to compare the relative thermal stability of purified A2 folded in vitro with I1Y, I1F, and RT peptides. A2/I1F and A2/I1Y complexes generated significantly higher melting temperatures (temperature at which 50% of the complexes have denatured) at 55 and 56 °C, respectively, compared with 48 °C for A2/RT (Fig. 1). Therefore, both I1F and I1Y peptides bind to A2 with higher affinity than RT. These results are consistent with the increased cell surface half-lives we have previously reported (10Pogue R.R. Eron J. Frelinger J.A. Matsui M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 8166-8170Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). In order to understand why they bind with higher affinity, we determined their crystal structures bound to A2. The x-ray crystal structures of the A2/I1Y and A2/I1F complexes were determined to a resolution of 2.2 and 2.8 Å, respectively. Both structures show clear, unambiguous density throughout the model. Overall, the A2/I1Y and A2/I1F structures are very similar to the RT structure (5Madden D.R. Garboczi D.N. Wiley D.C. Cell. 1993; 75: 693-708Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar) (r.m.s. deviations of 0.33 Å each when superpositioning the α-carbons of the peptide-binding super domains). The peptide positions are unambiguous in the density. The averaged omit maps for the I1Y and I1F peptides (see under “Materials and Methods”) are shown in Fig. 2, A and B. Both the I1Y and I1F peptides bind in the cleft in a conformation similar to that of the RT peptide, as shown in Fig. 2, C andD. The I1Y and I1F peptides have r.m.s. deviations of 0.33 Å and 0.25 Å for the α-carbon backbone of the peptides alone, respectively, based on the above superimposition of the α1/α2 domains onto the A2/RT α1/α2 domains. Upon completion of the crystal structure determinations, we looked for a reason for the increased affinity of the I1F and I1Y peptides as compared with RT. As the overall structures of the complexes are identical, we examined the peptides. In general, the paths of the main chain atoms of the peptides are identical. The side chain orientations of the P1 residues of the three peptides are similar, with the side chain pointing out of the binding cleft toward the TCR (Fig. 2,C and D). The aromatic rings of phenylalanine and tyrosine of I1F and I1Y are both oriented parallel to tryptophan-167 of the A2 binding cleft at a distance of 3.5 Å, suggesting these P1 substitutions allow stabilizing π-π orbital interactions with tryptophan-167. These π-π stabilizing interactions are not possible with the isoleucine in the wild-type peptide. The interaction of the P1 residue of I1Y peptide with tryptophan-167 is shown in Fig. 3 B. Next, we asked why T cell recognition is increased for the A2/I1F and A2/I1Y complexes compared with A2/RT. Examination of the structures shows one significant topological change to the surface of the TCR contact region when compared with the A2/RT complex. The P1 side chains I1Y and I1F protrude farther out of the peptide-binding cleft. The increased size of these amino acids increases the distance that the P1 side chain protrudes from the binding cleft by 2.9 and 1.6 Å, respectively. The only other difference between the structures of the I1Y peptide and the RT peptide, besides the substitution at the first position, is at the P4 glutamate. In the A2/I1Y structure, the P4 glutamate moves 0.6 Å from the RT position toward the P1 tyrosine. The distance between the tyrosine hydroxyl and the carboxylate of the glutamate is 5.7 Å and is too long for a direct hydrogen bond. The averaged omit map shows an elongated stretch of electron density perpendicular to the peptide backbone between the P1 and P4 residues, as shown in Fig. 4. This region of density is large enough to accommodate up to three waters at various occupancies. A water molecule within this stretch of electron density would be sufficient to bridge a hydrogen bond interaction between the tyrosine and the glutamate. However, the relatively low peak heights in the electron density maps suggest that these waters are not highly occupied. The side chain nitrogen of lysine-66 in the A2 binding cleft is sufficiently close to participate in a hydrogen bond with a water molecule that lies between the P1 and P4 residue as well. Conversely, in the I1F structure the glutamate at position 4 moves 1.1 Å (relative to the RT position) toward the carboxyl-terminal end of the peptide. Thus, the overall effect is to either move the glutamate side chain toward the potential hydrogen-bonding partner at P1 (in I1Y) or away from P1 (in I1F). In order to understand the potential effects that the P1 substitutions would have on TCR recognition, we modeled the P1 residues at the TCR/class I interface. There is close similarity at P1-P2 of the Tax peptide (leucine-leucine) in the TCR-MHC co-crystal structure (11Garboczi D.N. Ghosh P. Utz U. Fan Q.R. Biddison W.E. Wiley D.C. Nature. 1996; 384: 134-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (1212) Google Scholar, 12Ding Y.H. Smith K.J. Garboczi D.N. Utz U. Biddison W.E. Wiley D.C. Immunity. 1998; 8: 403-411Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar) and the RT peptide (isoleucine-leucine). Therefore, the structures of human αβ TCRs A6 (11Garboczi D.N. Ghosh P. Utz U. Fan Q.R. Biddison W.E. Wiley D.C. Nature. 1996; 384: 134-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (1212) Google Scholar) and B7 (12Ding Y.H. Smith K.J. Garboczi D.N. Utz U. Biddison W.E. Wiley D.C. Immunity. 1998; 8: 403-411Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar), both co-crystallized with A2/Tax peptide (LLFGYPVYV), provide a good model for comparing the TCR-MHC interactions between RT and I1Y/I1F. Both TCRs were modeled onto the A2/I1Y, A2/I1F, and A2/RT structures by superimposing the α1/α2 domains of our structures onto the α1/α2 domains of A2/Tax complex in each of the co-crystal structures. The r.m.s. deviations for the superimposition of the A2/TOX molecules in the A6 and B7 TCR co-crystal structures onto A2/RT were 0.50 and 0.42 Å. A model of the B7 TCR docked with A2/I1Y is shown in Fig. 3 A.
